title: Harry Maguire stat sums up just how poor Manchester United were against Newcastle
text:
Marcus Rashford once again struggled as Manchester United’s lead striker against Newcastle (Picture: Getty)

Matty Longstaff capped a dream Premier League debut with the winning goal in Newcastle’s 1-0 victory over Manchester United.

The result means Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s side are hovering just two points above the relegation zone, with just two wins from their opening eight matches of the 2019/20 campaign.

United are now without a win in their last 11 matches away from home which is their worst run in three decades.

Steve Bruce put his faith in local lad Longstaff – younger brother of Sean – and the 19-year-old more than repaid his manager with an outstanding performance from central midfield at St James’ Park.

The teenager beat David de Gea with a low drive from outside the box and the 72nd-minute strike proved decisive as the Magpies hung on for three points to pile yet more misery on Solskjaer’s men.

Advertisement

Advertisement

United’s whole attack looked bereft of ideas across the 90 minutes and Marcus Rashford once again failed to impress as Solskjaer’s lead striker.

Maguire had more touches of any United player inside the Newcastle box (Picture: Getty)

Cross after cross from Daniel James flashed across the box and one stat in particular hammered home just how poor United’s forwards were on Sunday evening.

Incredibly, central defender Harry Maguire had more touches (4) inside the opposition penalty area than any other United player on the pitch.

Solskjaer replaced Juan Mata with Mason Greenwood in an attempt to inject some life into United’s attack in the 66th minute but the 18-year-old failed to make a significant impact.

After the final whistle, Newcastle’s match-winner, Longstaff, said: ‘Last night you go to bed dreaming of it but you never think it will happen.

‘I’m over the moon, speechless.

‘I found out I was in the team yesterday after training, the butterflies started going and I looked forward to it ever since, I was buzzing.

Longstaff scored the only goal of the game on his Premier League debut (Picture: Getty)

On his goal, he added: ‘It was hit and hope and rather than a placed shot but it’s in the back of the net.

Advertisement

‘You can’t describe the feeling, running away to the fans, it was surreal.

‘I thought my first half shot was in but it hit the bar.

‘That was a bit disappointing but to get the goal front of the Gallogate, it’s that little bit special.’
